pull.title: doc: Suggest `keys.openpgp.org` as keyserver in SECURITY.md
pull.body: `--recv-keys` without a `--keyserver` arg simply failed for me on a fresh Arch Linux installation, so I think it's a good idea to suggest a keyserver. OpenPGP ecosystem is broken in a number of ways, so the right way to approach this issue has some potential for bikeshedding. But the only thing that this PR does is to keep `SECURITY.md` in line with the instructions for builder keys, where there was agreement on switching to `keys.openpgp.org` (#22688).

events.message:
doc: Suggest `keys.openpgp.org` as keyserver in SECURITY.md

This is in line with 4c43b7d41d11072f382f938379d21cd2e0bcbb47 from
PR #22688.

events.body: A related issue is that I couldn't find an unexpired version of @sipa's key, neither on `keys.openpgp.org` (which does not sync with other servers) nor somewhere else.
Wouldn't it make sense to update https://bitcoincore.org/en/contact/ as well, assuming that `keyserver.ubuntu.com` is non-functioning?

> Wouldn't it make sense to update [bitcoincore.org/en/contact](https://bitcoincore.org/en/contact/) as well, assuming that `keyserver.ubuntu.com` is non-functioning?

`keyserver.ubuntu.com` is functioning but I think we should just keep the keyserver consistent everywhere.
I think they don't accept any key updates, do they?

Review ACK 90f1f849e9f5a0c1855b72824af38b9aa24d5287

> keyserver.ubuntu.com is functioning but I think we should just keep the keyserver consistent everywhere.

I agree. Ideally we would not have to suggest any keyserver. It's frustrating enough to have to play keyserver ping-pong every time when yet another part of PGP infrastructure goes down, but it seems `keys.openpgp.org` works for now so let's use it consistently.

BTW instead of adding it in the command line every time you could also add
```
keyserver hkps://keys.openpgp.org
```
in `~/.gnupg/gpg.conf`

ACK 90f1f849e9f5a0c1855b72824af38b9aa24d5287

Makes sense to keep the keyservers consistent.
